input:
2. A 9-year-old girl is brought to the clinic due to a two-year history of worsening seizures and progressive loss of motor skills. Her parents note that she has developed frequent myoclonic jerks and has difficulty coordinating her movements, often stumbling and falling. She also complains of vision difficulties, including night blindness and decreased peripheral vision. Neurological examination reveals cognitive decline, spasticity, and mild ataxia. Brain MRI demonstrates diffuse cerebral and cerebellar atrophy, and an EEG shows generalized epileptiform activity. Ophthalmologic evaluation reveals optic nerve pallor and retinal degeneration. There is no known family history of similar symptoms, but genetic testing identifies mutations in the MFSD8 gene, confirming neuronal ceroid lipofuscinosis type 11. The patient is started on anticonvulsant therapy and referred for physical and occupational therapy to manage her symptoms and maintain quality of life.
What brings you in today?
output:
THINKING: The doctor is asking in simple terms why I'm here today. I need to explain my feelings and symptoms without getting too detailed or technical. I should mention what's bothering me the most and how it has changed recently.

ANSWER: I'm a 9-year-old girl, and I don't really understand everything, but I feel really tired and sometimes I get these weird jerks that I can't control. My eyes feel funny, and I keep bumping into things or stumbling a lot more than before. It just doesn't feel right, and I guess I’m worried because things are getting worse.

input: 2. A 9-year-old girl is brought to the clinic due to a two-year history of worsening seizures and progressive loss of motor skills. Her parents note that she has developed frequent myoclonic jerks and has difficulty coordinating her movements, often stumbling and falling. She also complains of vision difficulties, including night blindness and decreased peripheral vision. Neurological examination reveals cognitive decline, spasticity, and mild ataxia. Brain MRI demonstrates diffuse cerebral and cerebellar atrophy, and an EEG shows generalized epileptiform activity. Ophthalmologic evaluation reveals optic nerve pallor and retinal degeneration. There is no known family history of similar symptoms, but genetic testing identifies mutations in the MFSD8 gene, confirming neuronal ceroid lipofuscinosis type 11. The patient is started on anticonvulsant therapy and referred for physical and occupational therapy to manage her symptoms and maintain quality of life.Can you tell me more about when these episodes happen, how long they last, and if there are any specific things that seem to make them better or worse?
output: Um... it's kind of hard to say exactly. Sometimes it just happens randomly, and I don’t know why. They can last a few seconds or a bit longer, I think. Nothing I do really makes it better or worse, I guess. It just happens whenever, mostly.

The patient is started on anticonvulsant therapy and referred for physical and occupational therapy to manage her symptoms and maintain quality of life.Can you tell me more about what you experience during these episodes—what do they feel like, if anything makes them better or worse, and what you notice about how you feel before or after they happen?
output: Um, I don’t really know what’s happening, but I feel kind of funny and shaky, like I can’t control it. Sometimes it gets worse if I’m tired or excited, and after, I feel really tired and kind of out of it, like I don’t remember much.

input: 2. A 9-year-old girl is brought to the clinic due to a two-year history of worsening seizures and progressive loss of motor skills. Her parents note that she has developed frequent myoclonic jerks and has difficulty coordinating her movements, often stumbling and falling. She also complains of vision difficulties, including night blindness and decreased peripheral vision. Neurological examination reveals cognitive decline, spasticity, and mild ataxia. Brain MRI demonstrates diffuse cerebral and cerebellar atrophy, and an EEG shows generalized epileptiform activity. Ophthalmologic evaluation reveals optic nerve pallor and retinal degeneration. There is no known family history of similar symptoms, but genetic testing identifies mutations in the MFSD8 gene, confirming neuronal ceroid lipofuscinosis type 11. The patient is started on anticonvulsant therapy and referred for physical and occupational therapy to manage her symptoms and maintain quality of life.Can you tell me about what a typical day is like for you—how you sleep, what activities you do, and if there have been any recent changes or stresses at home or school?
output: Um, I guess I don’t sleep very well... I sometimes wake up a lot, and I feel really tired during the day, but I don’t know why. I also stumble more now and forget what I was supposed to do, and sometimes I get upset without knowing why. Things at home are kinda the same, but I guess I feel a little more tired than before.

Brain MRI demonstrates diffuse cerebral and cerebellar atrophy, and an EEG shows generalized epileptiform activity. Ophthalmologic evaluation reveals optic nerve pallor and retinal degeneration. There is no known family history of similar symptoms, but genetic testing identifies mutations in the MFSD8 gene, confirming neuronal ceroid lipofuscinosis type 11. The patient is started on anticonvulsant therapy and referred for physical and occupational therapy to manage her symptoms and maintain quality of life.Can you describe the jerking movements—do they happen suddenly, and do you notice any warning signs before they occur? Are they typically symmetric or asymmetric?
output: Um, sometimes I just start shaking all of a sudden, like my whole body jerks and I don't really expect it. I don’t notice anything before it happens, and it feels kinda weird, not like I can control it. They seem to happen all over me at once, not just one side.

Brain MRI demonstrates diffuse cerebral and cerebellar atrophy, and an EEG shows generalized epileptiform activity. Ophthalmologic evaluation reveals optic nerve pallor and retinal degeneration. The patient is started on anticonvulsant therapy and referred for physical and occupational therapy to manage her symptoms and maintain quality of life.Could you tell me how often these episodes happen each day or week, and whether you notice them mainly during certain parts of the day or night? Also, do you experience any warning signs or sensations before an episode begins?
output: Um, I think they happen kind of a lot, but I’m not really sure how many times, maybe every day but sometimes more or less? And it’s mostly when I’m trying to do stuff or at night, I guess. I don’t really notice anything before they start, just suddenly I feel all strange, but I don’t know what it is.

input: 2. A 9-year-old girl is brought to the clinic due to a two-year history of worsening seizures and progressive loss of motor skills. Her parents note that she has developed frequent myoclonic jerks and has difficulty coordinating her movements, often stumbling and falling. She also complains of vision difficulties, including night blindness and decreased peripheral vision. Neurological examination reveals cognitive decline, spasticity, and mild ataxia. Brain MRI demonstrates diffuse cerebral and cerebellar atrophy, and an EEG shows generalized epileptiform activity. Ophthalmologic evaluation reveals optic nerve pallor and retinal degeneration. There is no known family history of similar symptoms, but genetic testing identifies mutations in the MFSD8 gene, confirming neuronal ceroid lipofuscinosis type 11. The patient is started on anticonvulsant therapy and referred for physical and occupational therapy to manage her symptoms and maintain quality of life.Has she ever experienced episodes where she loses awareness completely, such as any blanking out or staring episodes? Also, has anyone observed her jerks—do they involve her whole body or just parts? And, has she had any EEG performed to monitor her brain activity during these episodes?
output: Um, I think sometimes she just kind of stares or looks like she’s gone for a moment, but I don’t know if she really fully loses consciousness. The jerks, um, they sometimes happen all over or just in one part—I’m not quite sure. No one’s really explained if they watched her brain during those times, so I don’t know if there’s been any test like that.

input: 2. A 9-year-old girl is brought to the clinic due to a two-year history of worsening seizures and progressive loss of motor skills. She also complains of vision difficulties, including night blindness and decreased peripheral vision. Neurological examination reveals cognitive decline, spasticity, and mild ataxia. Brain MRI demonstrates diffuse cerebral and cerebellar atrophy, and an EEG shows generalized epileptiform activity. Ophthalmologic evaluation reveals optic nerve pallor and retinal degeneration. There is no known family history of similar symptoms, but genetic testing identifies mutations in the MFSD8 gene, confirming neuronal ceroid lipofuscinosis type 11. The patient is started on anticonvulsant therapy and referred for physical and occupational therapy to manage her symptoms and maintain quality of life.Has anyone observed her staring episodes and noticed whether she appears to lose awareness completely, or does she seem aware during those times?
output: Um, sometimes she just kinda stares and doesn’t really move or say anything, but other times, I think she kinda knows I’m there, like she looks at us or blinks or something. It’s hard to tell if she’s really aware or not.

The patient is started on anticonvulsant therapy and referred for physical and occupational therapy to manage her symptoms and maintain quality of life.Does she experience her jerks in the morning shortly after waking, and have you noticed any triggers like sleep deprivation or flashing lights that seem to bring on her episodes?
output: Um, sometimes in the morning when she wakes up, she has those jerks. She doesn’t really talk about flashing lights or anything, but she seems to get tired or really sleepy, so maybe that’s when it happens? I’m not sure if anything else makes it worse.

Brain MRI demonstrates diffuse cerebral and cerebellar atrophy, and an EEG shows generalized epileptiform activity. Ophthalmologic evaluation reveals optic nerve pallor and retinal degeneration. There is no known family history of similar symptoms, but genetic testing identifies mutations in the MFSD8 gene, confirming neuronal ceroid lipofuscinosis type 11. The patient is started on anticonvulsant therapy and referred for physical and occupational therapy to manage her symptoms and maintain quality of life.Are you experiencing any sensitivity to flashing lights or visual triggers during your episodes, or have you noticed eyelid twitching or other specific features like sudden difficulty focusing before the jerks?
output: Um, sometimes when there are bright lights or flashing things, I kind of feel a little strange, like my eyes get more funny, but I can’t really tell if it’s the lights or the weird feeling I get. And my eyelids sometimes twitch a little, but I don’t know if that’s related. I just notice I have trouble focusing sometimes before I fall or do my jerks.

The patient is started on anticonvulsant therapy and referred for physical and occupational therapy to manage her symptoms and maintain quality of life.Has she noticed if her episodes tend to happen more during certain activities, times of day, or in relation to specific triggers like fatigue, stress, or flashing lights?
output: Um, I’m not really sure... sometimes they happen when I’m really tired or when I get upset, but I don’t think it’s always the same. I don’t know if anything specific sets them off.
